content: this episode we're gonna talk about miniature bases hello friends welcome
back to another episode of black magic crafts the last to many base six
episodes covered the various affordable brand options prepping your minis
removing mold lines and all that other jazz and now it's time for my favorite
part of the whole process basing your minis in this series I've set a certain
tone when it comes to prepping your miniatures and that tone being here's
some things you can do to improve the quality and look of your miniatures but
if you don't feel like doing it don't bother
who cares don't worry what other people think however this is one thing where
I'm going to strongly urge you to follow the advice and do this step and that is
basing your miniatures so let's talk about minis as they come out of their
package oftentimes when you open up your miniature you will find that they are
standing atop a little decorative sculptural base these are sometimes
referred to as pudding bases because it looks like they're just done a blob of
pudding I guess your first inclination as someone new to miniatures may be just
to paint this bad boy up and use it as is and you can do that you could in
theory just leave these on only their sculpted bases but there are a lot of
problems with this this is why I think it's important that you actually do this
one optional step these bases that are part of the sculpt of the mini vary
greatly in terms of size and shape some miniatures will stand really nicely on
top of them and be firm and secure and that's fine but many of them will knock
over very easily and this is the main reason I think you should put your
pieces on standard mini basis you don't want your minis easily falling over
during gameplay the other benefits of putting
your minis on standardized basis r1 I personally think it helps the aesthetic
quite a bit something about having a mini on a one inch round base is sort of
just classic in terms of that cool tabletop RPG vibe I don't know what it
is maybe it's just me personally but I think it's kind of the same thing as the
1 inch grid not something you absolutely need but somehow looks right in certain
situations the other advantage is that you can actually decorate those bases
this is optional some people like the idea that some people don't but if you
like the idea of decorating your bases and making them more scenic then you
definitely want to put them on a standard base the other thing I like
about it is it's a way to take all your minis from various manufacturers and
lines and put them on one cohesive platform so that you get some continuity
amongst your collection and this is why I tend to not use the included thin
miniature bases that come with the Wizkid's minis
I also don't use them because I don't like that they're thin but the main
reason is that they only come with those minis so all the wizkid minis would be
on bases that look different from all my other ones and I personally don't like
that might not matter to you but it matters to me for weird reasons after
painting minis for a while I finally decided that I wanted all my minis to be
on the same base I guess it really doesn't matter which base you choose as
long as they're all consistent in the same I personally chose the repr bases I
think the main reason I bought these is because they were the ones that my local
game store sold in bulk in a big tub and they're really cheap but they're also
really nice bases I have a bunch of Games Workshop bases that are slotted
and those are great for metal miniatures that have a slot to keep them secure but
for most minis for D and E they don't need that and it's just a hole you have
to cover I like the reaper ones because they're
smooth and solid and also that recess on the underside gives you a space to add
some wait to your miniatures in one way you
can achieve that is just by gluing in some coins or metal pieces or whatever
and that adds a nice weight to the bottom of your plastic miniature making
it feel more hefty when you play with it one last reason I like putting all my
minis on the same basis is a mechanical one if you just use these sculpted bases
then every miniature on the game table on your battle mat is going to be taking
up a different amount of space depending on the pose where in terms of rules and
mechanics of most RPGs there is some rule about the space a mini takes up in
the case of d5e that is a five-foot space having all your minis on the same
standard mini basis allows them to take up the same footprint on your dungeon
tiles or your battle mat making gameplay a lot clearer and smoother if you're
concerned about those movement rules so now that I've hopefully convinced you
to attach your miniatures to some bases let's talk about your different options
in doing so the fastest easiest no BS way you can do it is to simply superglue
your sculptural base right down to a plastic round base and be done you can
paint out the sculptural portion of the mini and leave the base black this is
fast this is easy a lot of people do it I personally really really dislike the
way it looks but that's just me it's a matter of taste I think why not just
make it a little bit nicer but hey it's all about what you think looks best you
do that and you're done if you want to kick it up a notch you
can start adding some terrain type texture to your miniature bases and
there's a bunch of different ways you can do this the easiest and cheapest way
is gluing down some sand just like you would on a piece of terrain however if
you are gluing sand to a plastic miniature base there's two things I'd
like you to keep in mind one is that you probably want to try to use a
finer grained sand with some big chunks in it rather than a coarse one because
of the scale of the mini you don't necessarily want it looking like it's
walking through boulders you probably want it looking like it's walking
through debris or dirt so the finer grits and the more appropriate it will
be to scale but again matter of taste and preference and not something you
need to worry about too much the other important thing to know when gluing sand
to a plastic miniature base is unlike terrain you don't want to do this with
PVA glue if you do that PVA glue will eventually separate and the sand will
peel away from the plastic base you'll have to glue it back on I've taken up
attaching my sand to many bases using superglue I just spread some superglue
over the base dunk the base in some sand shake off the excess rub off anything
that got over on the edge and let it harden up and this will make an
incredibly strong bond that will never come off
gluing sand down with superglue is not a very cost-effective thing to do on a
large scale but on many easier using so little that it's actually not very
expensive to do especially if you use the dollar store off-brand superglue
which I advise that you do in this case it's also important to make sure that
you keep the ring of the miniature clean and free of any sand if you have sand
that's glued down onto the rim on the sides it's gonna look messy and not
quite as nice take a little bit of effort just to wipe away any excess and
you'll have a nice clean division between base and terrain if you want to
kick it up another notch you can actually sculpt your bases using
two-part epoxy clay stuff like green stuff or Mille putt this is a great way
to create other textures like mud you just put some on the base and sculpt it
using some sculpting tools and some water and your fingers and whatever and
you're set you can also utilize stuff like the green stuff world textured
rolling pins which I'll put a link for in the description to create different
textures like cobblestone or or wood planks in the green stuff and
use that as your base that's what those rolling pins were actually for and they
are phenomenal at achieving this whether you're using sand or putty to sculpt a
base I encourage you to kind of cover and obscure the pre sculpted base that
comes on the mini so that it doesn't look disjointed unlike two different
textures going on sometimes this sculpted base that comes
on the mini is just too big too high so don't be afraid to cut it off
you can absolutely cut your mini free from its putting base prison and glue it
directly onto your beautiful nice sculpted base this is especially
effective when you have a sculpted base using a rolling pin pattern because then
you just see the base pattern and the feet sitting on it looking really
natural I suggest that if you're gonna do this though that you pin both feet
the same way I showed pinning that barbarians arm in the last episode all
of these methods of basing even if it's just gluing the mini directly to a
plastic base can then have flocking or static grass applied after your painting
is complete to add a little bit more dynamic scenery to the base now this
isn't for everybody some people don't like the idea of a mini tied to a grass
land base that you then have to use on tavern tiles or dungeon tiles and this
is a sacrifice if you choose to sculpt a base in a really scenic way it's not
going to look right on every scenario so you might want to leave it more generic
and just on a black base but for me I prefer my mini to look good all the time
when it's sitting on the shelf for the 99% of the time
exist if it doesn't match my tile completely in-game for you know 20
minutes it doesn't really bother me but that's personal preference and it's all
up to you there is another option of gluing your minis directly to clear
acrylic bases and that's a cool option too because then it shows your terrain
or battle maps through it that's a technique I haven't really done myself
but damn Scotty has a great video on the subject and I will put a link to that
video in the description once you start basing your minis you're gonna learn
something really quick and that's that a lot of miniatures come pre sculpted on
the bases that are wider than a standard mini base the pudding base will flare
out past the edges sometimes the pose of the feet is wider than the mini base and
that is really frustrating I don't know why sculptors do that you know that
these minis are to be used on a standard sized game why not sculpt your pieces in
a way that always fits a base I don't know maybe there's something I don't
realize about it drives me nuts but if you come across this you can get around
it by using the technique I talked about of cutting away the base and pinning
your model cut away all that excess so that's not overlapping and if the pose
has feet that are wider than a mini base don't be afraid to reposition bend them
and pin them so that they fit or even cut them off and modify them you can
have a lot of fun with this and it takes the hobby of mini painting and adds
another layer of development and fun to it because you can start kind of kit
bashing your pieces so that's it for this week
